Text: [Michael] I had the chance to sit down
with journalist and author Ben Blum,
who is one of the Stanford Prison Experiment's
most outspoken critics.
During our discussion,
he told me about his cousin Alex,
who was arrested for participating in a bank robbery
with his fellow Army Rangers,
and received a lenient sentence thanks to the testimony
of Dr. Zimbardo.
Alex isn't here today, but how does he feel now
about the lenient sentence he received because of Zimbardo?
Alex feels very conflicted.
He felt for years that it was unjust
for him to have served any time at all.
He really felt innocent.
He was so bitter for so long.
He felt that he'd had no choice but to go along.
I mean, being the victim of circumstance
is an incredibly frightening and powerless thing to be.
I think there's this kind of shallow comfort
that the Zimbardo narrative appears to give us.
None of us are really responsible
for the things we do wrong. We can't help ourselves.
We're just caught up in situations.
But to accept that
it to say that you're agentless.
Yeah. How am I ever going to avoid doing something horrible?
For a lot of years, he had a hard time accepting
responsibility for involvement in the crime.
And now I think he accepts that he really was guilty of a crime.
and that he deserved to go to jail for it.
So it sounds like taking personal responsibility...
admitting more control
helped Alex come to better terms with what happened,
and doesn't just feel like the victim of a circumstance.
So how does Alex feel about it today?
Alex has undergone a pretty dramatic
personal transformation.
Acknowledging that, actually,
there was a voice inside him
that did register what was going on.
There was a conscience at work
that he acted against.
Restored his faith in his own humanity.
And that was immensely liberating.
He and one of the tellers
in the bank that day have corresponded.
She said that she doesn't harbor any ill will toward him anymore.
And that's been really good for him.
